posts.title: New_feature,_Unit_placement
posts.html:
New feature, Unit placement

Something that I have been wanting to implement for a quite a while is unit placement. Unit placement is very important aspect of tactics in a game like this. It lets you decide where to place each unit on the battle field so that you for example can protect your ranged units and/or place your aggressive units at the front.

So, today I added this feature. Once you have selected your team you will see the battle arena with your units already arranged in some fashion but it lets you select the units individually and place them within two columns, depending if you start on the left or right side. However, it does not let you see what your oppenent unit placement is.

This feature required changes to many other systems which forced me to rethink some of those systems and also refactor some code. It works for all game modes in all my tests so now I'll just have to see what bugs show up when others test it.

Posted on Mon, 14 Jan 2019 by Andreas Olsson.

posts.title: You're_captured,_stupid_bug!
posts.html:
You're captured, stupid bug!

I found, with help from the dane, some annoying bugs today but they were hunted down and crushed.

The first bug was a silly rounding error when selecting a team. If you selected a stack of units, ie holding down shift, it rounded up rather than down when determining how many stacks you could afford of that unit. This allowed you to pick more units than you could afford.

The second bug was more tricky to track down but the error was just as silly. When a monster, is removed from the game, ie when it dies, I had forgotten to remove it from the waiting list. There are three lists for keeping track of the initiaitve order: will act, has acted, waiting. So, when a monster had waited and it would later be it's turn it would immediately be killed, which in turn removes that monster from the battle grid. At that time, though, that position on the grid might be occupied by another monster so you remove the wrong monster from the grid.

A third bug had been introduced when I made the last AI changes. The AI didn't end it's turn properly, so if there were more than one stack of the same monster the game wouldn't know which of these monster's turn it was.

Posted on Sun, 13 Jan 2019 by Andreas Olsson.

posts.title: UI_changes_to_character_sheet
posts.html:
UI changes to character sheet

I added the monster sprite, name and description to the character sheet so that you know what you are looking at. I have not yet added a description for all the monsters so currently it will just say "No description available".

I also took the time to update the ability compendium and the bestiary so that they also show the sprite for the monster/ability. It looks better and obviously makes it clearer what you are looking at.

The bestiary and ability compendium are now linked to in the lobby.

posts.title: AI_and_a_new_game_mode
posts.html:
AI and a new game mode

Today I added a game mode that lets you pit one AI against another AI. It can be interesting to watch the AI to see how it acts against different monsters and monster compositions.

My intention was for the game mode to be informative and a way to study AI behavior, maybe in preparation for a fight, but I found that it is quite fun to watch just watch them.

While I added this game mode I also added a second level of AI behavior. Previously there was only one AI behavior, level 1, that finds the closest enemey and tries to attack it with the most appropriate ability. It does this on every tile it is on. If it can't attack it it moves towards it instead, one tile at the time and reevaluates. But the new AI, level 2, prioritizes ranged enemies. If it can't attack it moves, and if it can't move it tries to attack the nearest enemy. More specifically, if it can't attack the ranged enemy and have no moves left it will run AI level 1 instead. There are more AIs to add but that will be another day.

Posted on Fri, 11 Jan 2019 by Andreas Olsson.
